thread.title: Do I Need a QMS if I Outsource My Medical Device Manufacturing?
thread.title_full: Do I Need a QMS if I Outsource My Medical Device Manufacturing?

author: Andrew Goodenough, Quality Assurance and Regulatory Affairs Manager, Integrated Technologies Ltd
title: Do I Need a QMS if I Outsource My Medical Device Manufacturing?
text:
As companies move to either develop or market a medical device for the first time the question of quality management system requirements is encountered.
This has given rise to several opinions on whether a documented and registered medical device quality management system in line with ISO 13485 is necessary.
Whilst ISO 13485 is not legally required, it is the most widely acceptable and expected QMS standard that meets the requirements of the medical device directive (93/42 EEC).
Here is some input from our Quality and Regulatory Affairs Manager:
In short, yes, your company will need a quality management system.
BUT.
It will only need to cover the elements that are applicable to the parts of the development, manufacturing and sales process that you don’t outsource.
When outsourcing some or all of the design, manufacture or sales of your medical device, your contract manufacturer will require more aspects of the QMS as they will be manufacturing and testing the device.
Medical Device Quality Management Systems in Practice
Where Integrated Technologies Ltd manufactures a complete device for a client a notified body would see them as a ‘critical subcontractor’.
Medical Device Academy explain critical suppliers and unannounced 13485 audits in this article .
Accordingly, ITL would be audited chiefly against elements of ISO 13485 such as:
Incoming goods inspection Non-conforming product Process validation Production controls The client, as the legal manufacturer, will not perform these functions and therefore could not be audited against them. They will however be audited by the notified body against aspects such as:
Device vigilance, Management review and objectives Technical file control Device history control Ongoing risk assessment (ISO 14971) Do I Need to Hire a Quality Manager?
Initially you should take guidance from a reputable regulatory consultant who will manage the required aspects of your quality management system. You will probably find that the established framework of ISO 13485 is recommended.
At this stage the quality consultant will normally visit the contract manufacturer to either audit or verify their QMS accreditation, and ensure that both you and your contract manufacturer agree a quality interface.
As the legal manufacturer and the contract manufacturer must work closely together, a manufacturing quality agreement in line with ISO 13485 and the Medical Device Directive is beneficial so that the responsibilities of each party can be clearly defined.
As the product or project develops and as your business allows, you should hire a quality manager tasked with running the QMS in-house. This will include the management of the contract manufacturer as a supplier.
To conclude, a QMS is required by the legal manufacturer in order to market medical devices under their own name. When outsourcing manufacturing or other elements of the development and/or sales process, the relevant QMS responsibilities pass to the contract manufacturer.
The work involved in setting up and maintaining a QMS will of course vary depending on the quantity, complexity and classification of your medical device.
